case_vignette: A mother brings her 4-year-old son to his pediatrician. Over the last eight months, her son has been exhibiting several "odd" behaviors. Most importantly, he repeatedly says that he is playing games with a friend named "Steven," though she is certain that he does not exist. She has often found him acting out magical scenarios as though someone else is present, when no one is there.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I keep talking to my friend Steven and playing magical games with him, even though my mom says he's not real.
Is this behavior affecting your sleep or appetite?
No, it doesn't seem to affect my sleep or appetite.
Is this imaginary friend a new development or has it been present for a long time?
Steven, my imaginary friend, has been around for the last eight months.

Have you experienced any separation anxiety or fear of being alone?

**Final Diagnosis:** Imaginary Friend Syndrome.
